A Washington dispatch, dated July 20th, to the Chicago Tribune, says that McClellan is greatly dissatisfied at Halleck being put over him. No good feeling exists between him and Pope.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Left my house on Saturday night, about 9 o'clk, my negro boy Waller.
He is about 5 feet 5 inches high, in his 19th year, has black skin and full eyes, and is generally well dressed.
He may be about some of the camps in this vicinity, or making for Fredericksburg, having been raised in the county of Caroline; or he may be about Mr. R. R. Sales's, of Ashland, who owns his mother.
I will give the above reward to any one who will deliver him to me at this place, or secure him so that I get him again, J. W. Ratcliffe,
Cor. 8th and Broad streets, Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Twenty-five dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on Friday last, July 25th, a negro Boy, Hubbard.
He is about 5 feet high, black, and has one short leg. The above reward will be paid, if delivered at the New Market, stall No. 4, or at Bacon's Quarter Branch.
[jy 29 --12t*] S. Schwartz.

div3.head: Married.
div3.p: To Richmond, July 31st, 1862, by the Rev. J. Magan, Mr. Wm. Bellam, of Petersburg, and Miss S. C. Trainham, of Henrico county, Va.
Petersburg Express please copy.

div4.p: Yesterday morning, at 8 o'clock, Mrs. Sarah A., wife of John W. Liggon, in the 49th year of her age.
Her funeral will take place this afternoon, at 4 o'clock, from her late residence, on Union Hill, Venable street. The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend. *
On Monday evening, 26th instant, Isabella Elizabeth, daughter of C. K. and Virginia E. Chapin, aged 2 years and 10 months.
The friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral from the residence of her father, on 9th st., one door beyond Leigh, this (Tuesday) evening, at 6 o'clock.
On Monday morning, 28th inst., at 4 o'clock, after an illness of four days, Roselmow, the youngest daughter of Joseph and Amanda Boliannon.

lg.l: Thy little head is pillowed now

div4.p: The funeral will take place to-day, (Tuesday,) at 4 o'clock. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend.
At the residence of Mr. Felix Mathews, in this city, on yesterday morning, of typhoid pneumonia, Claudius M., son of John T. and F. A. Anderson, of Hanover county, in the 21st year of his age.

His funeral will take place this morning, at 10 o'clock, from Grace Street Baptist Church.
The friends of the family are invited to attend. *
On Sunday, the 27th inst., of typhoid fever, Edward Warren Southall, aged 26 years.

The relatives and friends of his family are invited to attend his funeral from the residence of his mother, Mrs. Warren Southail, on Marion Hill, on this day, (Tuesday,) at 4 o'clock P. M., without further notice.

In the city of Petersburg, Va., on Saturday evening last, July 26th, after a severe but short illness, which she bore with Christian fortitude and resignation, Mrs. R. Amanda, beloved wife of Geo. W. Talbott, of Baltimore, Md., aged 32 years.-- "Requires cat in pace."
Baltimore papers please copy. *
On the 26th instant, after a painful and lingering illness, Coalter Macon, infant son of John J. and Mary L. Fallon, aged 6 months and 26 days.

lg.l: His little aching head is at rest,
Its throbbing and sufferings are o'er;
Will be heaved by affliction no more.

div4.p: At the residence of F. J. Barns, on Saturday, 26th inst., Lieut. Robert G. Haile, of company F, 55th Regiment Virginia Volunteers, who was wounded on Monday, 30th of June, in the battle before Richmond. *
On the 26th instant, from wounds received in the battle of the 27th June, at the residence of G. W. Wilson, in this city, Mr. John M. Moody, of company E, Orr's regiment S. C. Rities.
At the residence of her sister-in-law, on Mayo street, July 19th, at half past 11 o'clock, after a brief illness, Miss Susan L. Hatcher. *

div4.head: Obituaries.
div4.p: Died, in the city of Richmond, at the residence of Mr. L. R. Reins, on the 19th inst., David Myrick, of Southampton county, Va.

This noble youth was a member of Company F, of Norfolk.
A company known and reputed throughout its section for its caste, its intelligence, and its worth.
Enlisting at a time when patriotism needed not the stimulus of a bonus, nor love of country had merged into a miserable race after places of case, and positions of emolument, the noble impulses that led him to battle suffered not the taint of subsequent degeneracy.
Nature endowed him richly.
Frank, candid, and sincere, generous and disinterested, his beautiful character was not blemished by the deceit of the hypocrite, nor the greed of the miser.
Impulsive, enthusiastic, fiery when aroused, his lion heart knew the gentleness of the dove.
The tenderness of the woman, more than the roughness of the man, characterized him. For that virtue which we appreciate so highly — Courage — he was conspicuous.
In every skirmish, in every engagement, in every battle, he deported himself gallantly.
And in that great battle of Malvern Hill, the fiercest of the war, he exhibited an intrepidity and a daring that was brilliant and remarkable.
Charging with his company the battery that was scattering shot, shell, grape, canister, and shrapnel, upon that bloody field like autumnal leaves, he paused only when a Minnie ball stayed his advance.
To the expressions of sympathy from his General and Colonel, he replied with tears of regret that he could fight no longer.
But he had the glorious knowledge that his last shot, deliberate and well aimed, felled to the earth the Color Sergeant--him that bore the hateful ensign of the accursed invader.
But Davy lives no longer.
He has passed from earth to that "bourne whence no traveler returned. "

Dying away from home, he died not away from friends.
The kind-hearted gentleman at whose house he was, who had converted his home into a hospital for the sick and wounded of the company, his excellent wife, and their noble mother, her sons, his attending physician, and members of his company, were unremitting in their attentions.
Every kindness, every attention were lavishly bestowed.
No care, no pains were wanting to snatch him from the hands of death.
Every effort was unavailing.
He has passed from this world to that eternity which dwelled beyond, leaving behind him the tenderest affection of his grief-stricken family, and the most devoted attachment of his friends. [*] F.

head.foreign: Dulce et decorum est pro patria mori.

div4.p: Fell, on the battle-field of June 27th, Lt. Wm. C. Faith, Company E, 11th Reg't Ala. Vols.

While thousands have fallen bravely, none fell more bravely than did our promising young brother.
Promptly responding to the call of his country, he enlisted June 11th, 1861, and though only nineteen years of age, was elected to a Lieutenancy in his company, discharged the arduous duties of his position for a little more than twelve months, and at last gave his life as a free sacrifice for Freedom's cause.
Lt. F. stood high in the favor of his comrades, and bid fair to become one among the first officers of his regiment. J.
Mobile papers please copy. *

Richard A. Cosby, of Company E, (Black Eagle Company, from Cumberland,) 18th Virginia regiment, was killed almost instantly, by a shot in the head, in the fight on the Darbytown road, on Monday, the 30th ult., in a charge upon a Yankee battery, just as the battery was taken.
He died nobly, most gloriously, beside the enemy's captured guns.
And thus has fallen from our ranks one more patriot-martyr, one more brother.
We all loved him dearly; we all lament him sadly, while we proudly acknowledge that he was worthy thus to have died for his country. [*] Black Eagle.

div4.head: Tribute of respect.

dateline.name: Camp 2d Reg't La. Vols., Near Richmond

div4.p:
The Pelican Grays, company C, 2d Regiment Louisiana Volunteers, being desirous of expressing their feelings at the death of their late Captain. Bernard B. Hemken, who departed this life July 23d, 1862, of wounds received in the battle of Malvern Hill, July 1st, 1862, on motion Lieut. Griffin was called to the Chair, and the following committee appointed to draft resolutions: Lieut. N. L. Hardy, R. G. Cobb, J. P. Murphy, and P. R. Goldaby.
On motion, the Chairman was added to the committee.
The committee submitted the following preamble and resolutions, which were unanimously adopted by the company:

Whereas, it has pleased God, in His infinite wisdom, to take from our midst our loved and chosen Captain, Bernard B. Hemken, who fell mortally wounded while gallantly leading his company in the memorable charge of the 2d Louisiana regiment on the batteries of the enemy at Malvern Hill, cheering them on by his noble example: Therefore, be it

Resolved, That, in the death of Capt. Hemken, the South has lost one of its truest and bravest sons and defenders, one whose devotion to its cause knew no bounds, and whose life has sealed that devotion, and that Louisiana has lost one of the most noble and brilliant of that band of true young men whom she has sent to maintain her honor on the bloody field of strife with a remorseless and vindictive foe; and, further, that we (his company) feel that in his death we have lost an officer whose high sense of duty was unswerved by fear, favor, or reward, and whose qualities of head and heart had endeared him to us, his comrades in arms, since first we have known him, and that in him we feel that we have suffered an irreparable loss as friend, officer, and companion.

Resolved, That we deeply sympathize with the family of the deceased, in their grief for his early death, which, though the death a soldier would ever choose, must, from his intellectual, moral, and social worth, distress them sorely; and that a copy of these resolutions be furnished them as a token of our regard for the deceased, and heartfelt sympathy with them in this their severe afflictions.
Resolved, That these resolutions be published in the Richmond Dispatch and North Louisiana newspapers. *

div3.head: Thirty dollars reward.
div3.p: --The above reward will be paid for the arrest and delivery of the following deserters, residents of the counties of Surry and Prince George:
Description--James A. Pyland; height 6 feet 1 inch; complexion dark; hair and eyes dark; age 28 years.
Benj F. Wrenn; height 5 feet 10 inches; complexion dark; hair and eyes dark; eyes rather small; age 31 years.
Edwin J. Risby; height feet; complexion light; hair light; eyes blue; age about 26 years.
div3.closer:
C. S. Harrison, Capt. company D,
jy 29--1t* 10th battalion.

div3.head: Twenty recruits Wanted.
div3.p:
--For a company of cavalry in the Virginia State Line, commanded by Gen. J. B. Floyd.
This company is in service and only requires the above number to increase it to the maximum.
Horses and equipments furnished.
Persons desirous of joining this company will apply within ten days; after which no recruits will be received, unless by further orders of the commanding General.
Conscripts not received.
Apply at the recruiting office, opposite Spotswood Hotel.
div3.closer:
Capt. Edw'd McCONNELL, Jr.,
Lieut. David Johnson,
Recruiting Officers.
P. S.--A good steady man wanted for an Overseer. [ly 29--6t*] E. McC., Jr.

div3.head: Attention, Baltimoreans.
div3.p: --Capt. Edelin is now in Richmond, recruiting for the "Maryland Line." All disposed to join will find Sergt. Miller at the office, 10th street, between Main and Bank.

Come, boys, with us, and don't let others persuade you differently.
We have made a name, and don't, for God's sake, let it go down.
We will get "Old Maryland" out yet, as sure as the sun shines in Heaven.
div3.closer:
W. H. Miller,
jy 29--5t* Recruiting Sergt.

div3.head:
Headq'rs 5th Va. Cavalry,
Camp Cary, July 28th, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders no. 97.--All leaves of absences granted to members of this command previous to its regimental organization, are hereby revoked, and absentees will immediately report to their respective companies, or be considered as deserters.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. T. L. Rosser,
Thos. Hollingsworth.
jy 29--3t* 1st Lieut. and Adjutant.

div3.head: Attention.
div3.p: --All absent members of Co. K, 1st Va. Cavalry, not especially excused, are hereby ordered to report at camp at Hanover Court House, before Wednesday morning, or they will be published as deserters.
div3.closer:
G. P. Gaither, Jr.,
jy 29--3t* Capt. Co. K. 1st Va. Cavalry.

div3.head:
Hdq'rs Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond, July 26, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 25.
On and after Tuesday, the 29th of July, 1862, within the limits of the President's proclamation of martial law, it is hereby ordered that the maximum price of the following articles shall be--
Corn--$1.40 per bushel of 56 pounds.
Corn Meal--$1.50 bushel of 50 pounds.
Seed Oats--80 cts. bushel of 32 pounds
Clover Hay and Fodder--$1.75 per cwt.
Oats and Timothy Hay--$2 per cwt.
Shucks--$1.25 per cwt.
Straw--90 cts.
div3.closer:
Jno. H. Winder.
jy 28--ts Brig-Gen'l.
Enquirer and Whig please copy.

div3.p: All Members of the "Letcher Artillery" are hereby notified to report at camp, near Tree Hill, at 10 o'clock, this (Monday) morning, as the Battery is ordered to leave the neighborhood of Richmond.
